column2: CHAPTER XVI.
column3: CHAPTER sixteen.

column2: THE FIERCE FINISH OF SHILOH
column3: THE FIERCE FINISH OF SHILOH

column2: Dick, who had been lying under cover just behind the crest of one of the low ridges, suddenly heard the loud beating of his heart.
column3: Dick, who had been lying under cover just behind the crest of one of the low ridges, suddenly heard the loud beating of his heart.

column2: He did not know, for a moment or two, that the sound came so distinctly because the mighty tumult which had been raging around him all day had ceased, as if by a concerted signal.
column3: He did not know, for a moment or two, that the sound came so distinctly because the mighty tumult which had been raging around him all day had ceased, as if by a concerted signal.

column2: Those blinding flashes of flame no longer came from the forest before him, the shot and shell quit their horrible screaming, and the air was free from the unpleasant hiss of countless bullets.
column3: Those blinding flashes of flame no longer came from the forest before him, the shot and shell quit their horrible screaming, and the air was free from the unpleasant hiss of countless bullets.

column2: He stretched himself a little and stood up.
column3: He stretched himself a little and stood up.

column2: The lads all around him were standing up, and were beginning to talk to each other in the high-pitched, shouting voices that they had been compelled to use all day long, not yet realizing to the full that the tumult of the battle had ceased.
column3: The lads all around him were standing up, and were beginning to talk to each other in the high pitched, shouting voices that they had been compelled to use all day long, not yet realizing to the full that the tumult of the battle had ceased.

column2: The boy felt stiff and sore in every bone and muscle, and, although the cannon and rifles were silent, there was still a hollow roaring in his ears.
column3: The boy felt stiff and sore in every bone and muscle, and, although the cannon and rifles were silent, there was still a hollow roaring in his ears.

column2: His eyes were yet dim from the smoke, and his head felt heavy and dull.
column3: His eyes were yet dim from the smoke, and his head felt heavy and dull.

column2: He gazed vacantly at the forest in front of him, and wondered dimly why the Southern army was not still there, attacking, as it had attacked for so many hours.
column3: He gazed vacantly at the forest in front of him, and wondered dimly why the Southern army was not still there, attacking, as it had attacked for so many hours.

column2: But the deep woods were silent and empty.
column3: But the deep woods were silent and empty.

column3: Coils and streamers of smoke floated about among the trees, and suddenly a gray squirrel hopped out on a bough and began to chatter wildly.

column2: Dick, despite himself, laughed, but the laugh was hysterical.

column2: He could appreciate the feelings of the squirrel, which probably had been imprisoned in a hollow of the tree all day long, listening to this tremendous battle, and squirrels were not used to such battles.
column3: He could appreciate the feelings of the squirrel, which probably had been imprisoned in a hollow of the tree all day long, listening to this tremendous battle, and squirrels were not used to such battles.

column2: It was a trifle that made him laugh, but everything was out of proportion now.

column2: The ordinary occupations were gone, and people spent most of their time trying to kill one another.
column3: The ordinary occupations were gone, and people spent most of their time trying to kill one another.

column3: The last rosy glow of the sun faded, and thick darkness enveloped the vast forest, in which twenty thousand men had fallen, and in which most of them yet lay, the wounded with the dead.
